title: How to Add Rows to a Pivot Table

steps.title: Review your source data.
steps.content: Review your source data. Click the tab that contains the data you're using in your pivot table, and make sure it contains the data you want to use to create your new row. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source For example, if you want to add a row for a specific purchase, make sure that purchase is listed in the appropriate column in your source data.

steps.title: Click any cell in the PivotTable.
steps.content: Click any cell in the PivotTable. This opens the PivotTable Fields panel on the right side of Excel. [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source If you have already moved the appropriate field to the Rows area but don't see a row that's in your source data, just press Alt + F5 or right-click the pivot table and select Refresh . [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Drag a field into the "Rows" area on PivotTable Fields.
steps.content: Drag a field into the "Rows" area on PivotTable Fields. When you drag any of the fields in the upper portion of the PivotTable Fields panel to Rows, a new row will be added to your table. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Rows are usually non-numeric fields, such as column headers. Numbers will usually go into the Values area. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Reorder the field labels in the "Row Labels" section.
steps.content: Reorder the field labels in the "Row Labels" section. If you already have a field in the Rows area, adding another row below that will nest the new row within the existing row. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source You can drag the rows up or down to change which row is nested within the other.

steps.title: Review your source data.
steps.content: Review your source data. Click the tab that contains the data you're using in your pivot table, and make sure it contains the data you want to use to create your new row. For example, if you want to add a row for a specific purchase, make sure that purchase is listed in the appropriate column in your source data.

steps.title: Click anywhere in your pivot table.
steps.content: Click anywhere in your pivot table. This opens the pivot table editor on the right side of Google Sheets.

steps.title: Click Add under "Rows."
steps.content: Click Add under "Rows." It's in the left side of the pivot table editor. A list of fields will expand on the menu. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Click the name of the field you want to add as a row.
steps.content: Click the name of the field you want to add as a row. Rows are usually non-numeric fields, such as category names and/or column headers. Once you select a field, a new row or rows will be added for the items in that field. [8] X Research source You can also drag any of the labeled fields from the right side of the pivot table panel directly to the Rows area.

steps.title: Rearrange your rows as needed.
steps.content: Rearrange your rows as needed. If you have multiple rows, adding a new row under an existing row will nest the new row within the existing row. You can drag the row field names up or down to change the order if you want to change the nesting order. [9] X Research source
